I have a mixed opinion on some of the content that is posted on this channel, and this video perfectly illustrates that. In some other videos were the subject is a "simple" thing (actually not so simple) like a lake topped with plastic balls, a vehicule that navigates faster than the wind, a basket ball travelling in an odd way, and you provide a complete explanation of these oddities. You found a lot of fascinating subjects like this, the one about Penrose tiles for instance is astonishing.

And then there are videos like this. We're no longer in the realm of truth and facts here, despite the name of the channel. These videos (sponsored or not) glorify some megalomaniac wet dreams from the Silicon Valley, there are mot about promises of things that may or may not happen and work, not about facts. The way you film shiny metal, clean factories (where no one seems to actually be working?), with slow travellings and clean lighting, it gives the impression that we're seeing a commercial film about a showroom in a car exhibition. Which is actually the case when we see the part about... Tesla!? Why on earth mention Tesla here, while we're talking rockets, not cars? And why with the clean, commercial-looking images that look like they came out of Tesla's official press kit? And what about the video where you interviewed that man who predicted that tech would make us immortal? Is that "truth" ?

I understand that you need to make ends meet, and that sponsoring may involve making compromises. But if these compromise go too far, you may lose the respect or trust of some part of your viewers. I personnally enjoy your content about basket balls and tiles, that's were you could show your specific talents and knowledge; this... looks like commercial communication that I could see on a start up's website.

Through Christ’s sacrifice we gain Salvation through God’s abundant mercy and grace. We are reconciled and recompensed back to God, through the shed blood of His beloved Son Christ Jesus.
John chapter 3 verse 16: "For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whosoever believes in Him, shall not perish, but have everlasting life.”
Romans chapter 5 verse 8: "But God demonstrates His love toward us, in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.”

Christ came to undo the sin and eternal death brought upon the world through the sin of Adam.
Death in Adam, Life In Christ:
Romans chapter 5 verse 19: "For as by one man’s disobedience (Adam), many were made sinners, so also by one Man’s (Jesus) obedience, many will be made righteous.”
Romans chapter 5 verse 18: "Therefore, as through one man’s (Adam’s) offense judgement came to all men, resulting in condemnation, even through one Man’s (Christ’s) righteous act, the free gift came to all men, resulting in the justification of life.”

Romans chapter 5 verse 21:
“So that as sin reigned in death, even so grace might reign through righteousness to eternal life through Jesus Christ our Lord.”

1 Corinthians 15 : 21-22, “For since by man(Adam) came death, by Man(Christ), also came the resurrection of the dead. For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ, all shall be made alive.”
Christ’s sacrifice, the crucifixion of His flesh, brings reconciliation of sins, resurrection, eternal life and salvation.

Christ is Salvation. Christ is our Lord and Saviour. Christ is the only way to God. Christ is the only Mediator between God and men (us humans).

"He is the image of the invisible God, the firstborn over all creation. For by Him all things were created that are in heaven and that are on earth, visible and invisible, whether thrones or dominions or principalities or powers. All things were created through Him and for Him.”

"In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God. He was in the beginning with God. All things were made through Him, and without Him nothing was made that was made. In Him was life, and the life was the light of men.”

Say: "What thing is most weighty in evidence?" Say: "Allah is witness between me and you; This Qur'an hath been revealed to me by inspiration, that I may warn you and all whom it reaches. Can ye possibly bear witness that besides Allah there is another Allah?" Say: "Nay! I cannot bear witness!" Say: "But in truth He is the one Allah, and I truly am innocent of (your blasphemy of) joining others with Him."
20. Those to whom We have given the Book know this as they know their own sons. Those who have lost their own souls refuse therefore to believe.
21. Who doth more wrong than he who inventeth a lie against Allah or rejecteth His signs? But verily the wrong-doers never shall prosper.
22. One day shall We gather them all together: We shall say to those who ascribed partners (to Us): "Where are the partners whom ye (invented and) talked about?"
23. There will then be (left) no subterfuge for them but to say: "By Allah our Lord, we were not those who joined gods with Allah."
24. Behold! how they lie against their own souls! But the (lie) which they invented will leave them in the lurch.
25. Of them there are some who (pretend to) listen to thee; but We have thrown veils on their hearts, So they understand it not, and deafness in their ears; if they saw every one of the signs, not they will believe in them; in so much that when they come to thee, they (but) dispute with thee; the Unbelievers say: "These are nothing but tales of the ancients."
26. Others they keep away from it, and themselves they keep away; but they only destroy their own souls, and they perceive it not.
27. If thou couldst but see when they are confronted with the Fire! They will say: "Would that we were but sent back! Then would we not reject the signs of our Lord, but would be amongst those who believe!"
28. Yea, in their own (eyes) will become manifest what before they concealed. But if they were returned, they would certainly relapse to the things they were forbidden, for they are indeed liars.
29. And they (sometimes) say: "There is nothing except our life on this earth, and never shall we be raised up again."
30. If thou couldst but see when they are confronted with their Lord! He will say: "Is not this the truth?" They will say: "Yea, by our Lord!" He will say: "Taste ye then the penalty, because ye rejected Faith."
31. Lost indeed are they who treat it as a falsehood that they must meet Allah,- until on a sudden the hour is on them, and they say: "Ah! woe unto us that we took no thought of it"; for they bear their burdens on their backs, and evil indeed are the burdens that they bear?
32. What is the life of this world but play and amusement? But best is the home in the hereafter, for those who are righteous. Will ye not then understand?
33. We know indeed the grief which their words do cause thee: It is not thee they reject: it is the signs of Allah, which the wicked condemn.
34. Rejected were the messengers before thee: with patience and constancy they bore their rejection and their wrongs, until Our aid did reach them: there is none that can alter the words (and decrees) of Allah. Already hast thou received some account of those messengers.
35. If their spurning is hard on thy mind, yet if thou wert able to seek a tunnel in the ground or a ladder to the skies and bring them a sign,- (what good?). If it were Allah's will, He could gather them together unto true guidance: so be not thou amongst those who are swayed by ignorance (and impatience)!
36. Those who listen (in truth), be sure, will accept: as to the dead, Allah will raise them up; then will they be turned unto Him.
37. They say: "Why is not a sign sent down to him from his Lord?" Say: "Allah hath certainly power to send down a sign: but most of them understand not.
38. There is not an animal (that lives) on the earth, nor a being that flies on its wings, but (forms part of) communities like you. Nothing have we omitted from the Book, and they (all) shall be gathered to their Lord in the end.
39. Those who reject our signs are deaf and dumb,- in the midst of darkness profound: whom Allah willeth, He leaveth to wander: whom He willeth, He placeth on the way that is straight.
40. Say: "Think ye to yourselves, if there come upon you the wrath of Allah, or the Hour (that ye dread), would ye then call upon other than Allah?- (reply) if ye are truthful!
41. "Nay,- On Him would ye call, and if it be His will, He would remove (the distress) which occasioned your call upon Him, and ye would forget (the false gods) which ye join with Him!"
42. Before thee We sent (messengers) to many nations, and We afflicted the nations with suffering and adversity, that they might learn humility.
43. When the suffering reached them from us, why then did they not learn humility? On the contrary their hearts became hardened, and Satan made their (sinful) acts seem alluring to them.
44. But when they forgot the warning they had received, We opened to them the gates of all (good) things, until, in the midst of their enjoyment of Our gifts, on a sudden, We called them to account, when lo! they were plunged in despair!
45. Of the wrong-doers the last remnant was cut off. Praise be to Allah, the Cherisher of the worlds.
46. Say: "Think ye, if Allah took away your hearing and your sight, and sealed up your hearts, who - a god other than Allah - could restore them to you?" See how We explain the signs by various (symbols); yet they turn aside.
47. Say: "Think ye, if the punishment of Allah comes to you, whether suddenly or openly, will any be destroyed except those who do wrong?
48. We send the messengers only to give good news and to warn: so those who believe and mend (their lives),- upon them shall be no fear, nor shall they grieve.
49. But those who reject our signs,- them shall punishment touch, for that they ceased not from transgressing.
50. Say: "I tell you not that with me are the treasures of Allah, nor do I know what is hidden, nor do I tell you I am an angel. I but follow what is revealed to me." Say: "can the blind be held equal to the seeing?" Will ye then consider not?
51. Give this warning to those in whose (hearts) is the fear that they will be brought (to judgment) before their Lord: except for Him they will have no protector nor intercessor: that they may guard (against evil).
52. Send not away those who call on their Lord morning and evening, seeking His face. In naught art thou accountable for them, and in naught are they accountable for thee, that thou shouldst turn them away, and thus be (one) of the unjust.
53. Thus did We try some of them by comparison with others, that they should say: "Is it these then that Allah hath favoured from amongst us?" Doth not Allah know best those who are grateful?
54. When those come to thee who believe in Our signs, Say: "Peace be on you: Your Lord hath inscribed for Himself (the rule of) mercy: verily, if any of you did evil in ignorance, and thereafter repented, and amend (his conduct), lo! He is Oft-forgiving, Most Merciful.
55. Thus do We explain the signs in detail: that the way of the sinners may be shown up.
56. Say: "I am forbidden to worship those - others than Allah - whom ye call upon." Say: "I will not follow your wain desires: If I did, I would stray from the path, and be not of the company of those who receive guidance."
57. Say: "For me, I (work) on a clear sign from my Lord, but ye reject Him. What ye would see hastened, is not in my power. The command rests with none but Allah: He declares the truth, and He is the best of judges."
58. Say: "If what ye would see hastened were in my power, the matter would be settled at once between you and me. But Allah knoweth best those who do wrong."
59. With Him are the keys of the unseen, the treasures that none knoweth but He. He knoweth whatever there is on the earth and in the sea. Not a leaf doth fall but with His knowledge: there is not a grain in the darkness (or depths) of the earth, nor anything fresh or dry (green or withered), but is (inscribed) in a record clear (to those who can read).
60. It is He who doth take your souls by night, and hath knowledge of all that ye have done by day: by day doth He raise you up again; that a term appointed be fulfilled; In the end unto Him will be your return; then will He show you the truth of all that ye did.
61. He is the irresistible, (watching) from above over His worshippers, and He sets guardians over you. At length, when death approaches one of you, Our angels take his soul, and they never fail in their duty.

A couple things the engineer said about the printed rocket were pretty dubious.  Any roughness or texture will induce drag.  I don't know why he is claiming otherwise.  Also, the roughness can create structural weakness if it acts as a flaw.  For example, if the space between two outcroppings is a little too deep, it can have the characteristics of a crack.  The crack can grow or become a weak spot.  It is like having a tiny pit in a windshield that becomes the source of a giant crack.  Making it thicker doesn't do anything to stop a crack from growing.  This is basic material science.  They should really make the surfaces, inside and outside, smooth and uniform.

I love the idea. I've been watching 3D printing grow to serious industry for a while now, but haven't seen something this ambitious. However, there is something that may need to be considered and that is the standardized testing that is typically performed on equipment like this before it is considered flight/space worthy. Currently, Non-destructive testing (NDT) is performed using many techniques, all of which are designed to look for discontinuities on material surfaces or porosities in welds, etc. When things are 3D printed they are not formed or created in the same manner and so they may or may not have the same types of flaws that are found by modern methods searching for these flaws. I mean to say, it is hard to tell what types of imperfections or flaws we might see as the norm within 3D printing. It could be that the material is better in every way. There just needs to be more testing and research in these larger scale things that 3D printers can create.

(By AMA) To whom it may concern.
The Key to making an over unity Electric generator work is mechanical advantage. In this case the mechanical advantage is achieved by getting the electric motor that is spinning to be able to spin a quantity of separate discs that are connected to devices that generate electrical current to generate more current then the electric motor needs to spin. One of the ways to achieve this without violating the laws of thermo dynamics is to exploit magnetic field effects. To do this you place the magnets on the disc that the electric motor is spinning in a way that makes it so while the disc is spinning around the magnetic fields are slamming upwards onto the edge of the other discs forcing them to spin, thereby generating electric current. In this way, the magnetic fields will be forced to do work that the electric motor wont be doing. This is how it's possible to achieve an Over Unity Electric generator & with this technology we can free ourselves from the use of gas. (By AMA)

The concept is amazing! The only practical complication that I see is in the maintenance of such rockets. When a thing is manufactured by parts assembly, the advantage is that if anything goes wrong, you take out that part and replace it with a new part. But if that component is embedded in the structure of the machine and it goes wrong, replacing or repairing it will be a whole different ball game which most certainly wont be easy.

Interesting... But the question of laminar flow within tubing was completely sidestepped. Residential copper piping develops pin-hole leaks over time due to the disruption of laminar flow when plumbers fail to properly deburr pipe ends. I can only imagine what a 3D printed pipe is going to do with high speed rocket fuel racing through it during a launch event. I feel like the smooth wall laminar flow problem is probably the biggest problem that needs to be solved in fully 3D printed rocket engines. The rest is just boring engineering detail in comparison.

It actually makes a lot of sense for 3d printed parts to be sturdier than their contemporary counterparts. While contemporary welding has a variation in density and tensile strength focused on the weld lines, 3d printed parts are able to spread applied forces around their entire structure, which puts less stress on any one part.

Seriously, what's the point in making the fuel tanks and body in a 3D metal printer? The aluminium needs to be rolled or extruded then drawn into wires in the first place, which refines the grain and gives it better properties. Then you melt it in plasma, which needs power and welding gasses, and you loose the grain refinement to boot. Or you could just make it out of rolled or extruded aluminium sheet and weld, bolt, rivet or even glue it together at the seams.

17:44 "100 times cheaper" - using the word 'times' when talking about a comparative reduction really bothers me. Presumably he means it's 1/100th of the cost, but the phrase doesn't actually mean that.

Imagine two gizmos. The first costs $1000 and the second is $1 cheaper (i.e. it's $999). Now, if there were a third gizmo that were "100 times cheaper" than the second, we would multiply the original amount cheaper ($1) by 100 = $100. Then subtract that $100 from the price of the first gizmo ($1000) to find that the third gizmo costs $900. So the third gizmo is 100 times cheaper than the second, but not 1/100th the cost of anything.

For one thing to be a multiple of a reduction less than another thing, there must be an original reduction for us to multiply.

10:15 This is a BIG claim that some multi-billion dollar engineering firms have learned the hard way is NOT necessarily true! I'm an aerospace engineer and looking at the surface of that rocket makes me cringe... hard. 3D printing is an alluring process, but there is a reason that successful applications have been limited to SMALL parts, not entire rockets. The issue is the mechanical design limits you can work with have wild variance and you need EXTENSIVE testing with each alloy and process to get your hands around it. Getting a reliable S-N curve, Goodman limit, or even just dumb isotropic yield strength is tremendously difficult with this production method. You can try and recover strength by post-treating the surfaces (e.g. post-machining, HIP [lol, for a whole fuel tank?!], peening, or other heat treatments) but the fatigue allowables are still lousy because of all the inevitable inclusions. Else, you just have to rely on wicked good process control while designing to limit peak stress and cyclic loading. Good luck with that in a full-up rocket.

Also, materials science and materials engineering are NOT the same things. Just because you can produce an alloy that performs well as a coupon doesn't mean that those properties will hold ubiquitously on a macro scale. I just hope these fellow StarCraft aficionados have accounted for this or the stresses are distributed enough thanks to the unibody design that this thing can survive til MECO before turning into confetti!

it is definitely more look like hi-tech than achieving actual purpose. 3D printing of metals is more like welding like TIG or MIG process. There is a chance of having more defects at micro level than usual welding process. 60 day of power consumption, 60 days of constant production of toxic gases, most of the wire also goes into slag due to oxidation.
Rolling of actual steel sheets and welding them sections is more faster, and reduces possibility of micro level pores and crack due to printing, and even many non destructive testing methods like florescent test, X-ray testing etc can detect.
That is why space X is using reusable steel rocket boosters.
To fail a space craft, a tiny bit of fault is enough to violently explore everything, i think columbia space shuttle damage is caused a small fault in O rings that fit inside steel cylinder.

Bending steel sheets or plates (>6mm) is much easy, and cold rolling also eliminates any surface defects and also strengthen the surface and structure.

As a 79 year old who started as a draughtsman in 1957 using a pencil then pen and ink from a bottle on paper or linen, 3D printing direct from CAD designs is wonderful progress. The first electronic calculator with the amazing square root button did away with ten figure logarithm tables and the slide rule. The first time using Autocad v1.0 on an 8087 PC with 640Kb of RAM was a huge advance. Using the maximum of 16 colours available on the graphics card where each colour could drive a tool on a CNC machine was another leap forward. Now I fix peoples computers when they get the 'blue screen of death'! Such wonderful progress - and it still coming!

All of these Mars colonisation lovers (myself included) romanticise the idea of humans moving out into the solar system, but they miss out on talking about the massive practical benefit of a working space industry - space mining - it could end up reducing the destruction of our only habitable planet. The first company to bring a suitable asteroid from the Belt into the Earth-moon system will have done more to further the industry than all the settlements on the Moon and Mars. Apparently the belt has worth $100 billion per human in current value of minerals.

In the late 1950's my father Ken Early a Boeing manufacturing research metal forming specialist, patented a process: Axial Load Bulge Forming to produce complex parts in one piece without welds, cracking or wall thinning from very high temp "exotic metals" (Inconel, Hasteloy-X, Rene-41), which were considered almost impossible to form into the useful shapes aerospace needed, solving a critical problem holding back the fledgling industry.

At the time, complex rocket nozzles, jet engine combustion chambers, NASA spacecraft parts produced by the local Seattle company he co-founded: Exotic Metals Forming Inc could only be manufactured by the revolutionary EMF bulge forming process. As a creative metal forming engineer he would have loved the success Relativity and their unique problem solving skills offer the industry. Well done to everyone involved.

This is going to sound wack, but this video made me recall something I read decades ago. Allegedly, information leaked about the memory metal collected at the Roswell UFO crash site suggested that it was a fairly conventional aluminum alloy, but built up from layers of a continuous, microscopic weld. Do I believe that an extraterrestrial/interdimensional vehicle crashed at Roswell? Not exactly. In light of recent disclosures, I neither believe it, nor can I rule it out. What I am saying is, the description that was floating around back in the 1980s of UFO material describes what this company is doing, except that the UFO stuff was much more finely-made. While it's cool, to me it looks more like some hype and not the future of production of this kind of thing, even if conventional specialized machinery has some work to do in achieving more flexibility and customizability in the production of pieces. Generally non-"printing" welding should be able to make the same piece less expensively and less wastefully than "printing." If it's something intended to produce more of that given thing, rather than a single unit, it would probably be always preferable, with "printing"/layered welding being more of a tool for things one does not intend to ever build any more units. And even then there could be building tools other than "3d printers" that do a better job at things with a certain level of customization/uniqueness, as long as it's made from parts that are close enough to things that are in production by such specialized tools.

17:59 The sad realistic picture of why “impactful” rich people want to go to Mars is probably because it’s a perfect opportunity for establishing a complete monopoly. Anyone who gets there first has the power to take any potential resources for themselves for more profit. For instance, on Earth, China is slowly establishing a monopoly because “green energy” products require an astronomical amount of RARE metals, which China has a lot. And the ironic thing is, that these products end up doing more damage to the environment than the current ones solely because of the requirements of manufacture and the careless behaviour toward using the resources in an environmentally friendly way. The same goes for the West and it’s fossil fuels, but that is slowly running out of interest. I’m not saying that I’m against space exploration, in fact, I love it and hope to work in that field one day. It’s just sad that what normal people think of as “the next step in the future for humanity” is probably just an opportunity for big world-leading industries to exploit us even more.
That would also lead to exploitation of Mars’s resources which would create the same situation as here. I just hope that I’m wrong (even thought I doubt it currently) and that some of us make a difference to turn this into the right direction.

Here is the problem with 3 D Printing with metal.
The energy to convert Bauxite into sheet Aluminium or into welding wire requires a similar amount of energy.
The next conversion comparison is from sheet Aluminium to a tube verses from welding wire to a tube.

In the first case from sheet material, you just roll it, very little Time/energy required.
From welding wire to a tube you will use about 200 amps at about 26 volts with a travel speed of about 350mm /Min. This gives you just under 1 kJ per MM .... imagine how many MM of travel if it does in one day. 1 day x 24 x 60mins =1440 mins X 1 kJ each min = 1440 KJ per Min = 1440 kJ, times the number of days .... that's a lot Time/energy, more than simply rolling a piece of sheet Aluminium.

This video could give the impression 3D Printing is a good Idea in all instances.

I'm highly skeptical of their claim that their 3D-printed parts are stronger than traditionally forged parts. His explanation about "taking advantage of the physics principal of heating and cooling quickly" sounds like hand-waving to me.
The main drawback with 3D-printed metals is they are more susceptible to metal fatigue due to small imperfections along the grain. These faults create a weak link that can lead to inconsistent material properties that I have a hard time believing their special alloy recipe can overcome.
I'd like to see hard numbers comparing strength of metals fabricated via the two methods.
Given the nature of rocket launches where there is little margin for error, and even the smallest fault can lead to catastrophic failure, I would like to see significant evidence that these parts are reliable. And even if they can survive a single launch, I certainly wouldn't trust them to be reusable.

But, doubts aside - I nonetheless applaud this company for working to push the technology forward, and help bring humanity further into space and Mars!

Solid fuel rockets are inherently much simpler:  they hollow a core down the middle of the propellant, so it burns from the inside out.  The out propellant layer shields the rocket side from the heat;  the last of the propellant burns out same time, before the rocket sides heat up enuf to melt.   The rocket is made to a size such that when the propellant is all burnt, the payload is where it is wanted to be.  The nozzles are made from a carbon goo, machined to the nozzle shape, that doesnt reach the melt temp.

Around 5:15 Scott mentions that the rough surface from the printing has the same aerodynamic performance as a non-3d printed one. To me this seems wild, but also a little unexplainable.

Early on in-flight training, we learn that parasite drag affects the aerodynamics of an aircraft (as the force that opposes thrust). This is composed of 1) form drag which is the shape of the aircraft and 2) skin drag - which refers to the smoothness of the external surfaces of the aircraft.

Most aerospace manufacturers will therefore try and mitigate drag as much as practical, to increase efficiency & performance. It seems weird that Relativity Space has gone for a different approach.

This raises some questions
- Does the rough surface really perform identically to a smooth one for rocket applications? If yes, how/why?
-Or is skin drag relatively negligible when compared to wave and form drag? ( I assume induced drag from the fins is relatively low -given rockets rely on ballistics rather than lift for propulsion.)

The math illiteracy of the interviewee is stunning. I really hope he's not the one doing the calculations.

Why do I say that? He used nonsensical and inaccurate phrasing like "100 times fewer" no less than three times.

If your product has 20 parts instead of 100, your product does NOT have "five times fewer parts".
Five times fewer is NEGATIVE 400 parts... not 20.
100 original parts subtracting 5 times that amount... 500... gives you a nonsensical answer: negative 400. (100-500=-400)

Proper math, and proper English, requires you to say "My product has one-fifth the number of parts of a traditional system." or "My product uses just twenty percent of the number of parts of a traditional system." or "Traditional systems use five times the parts as our design.", but saying "My product has five times fewer parts" just makes you sound like an idiot. (It has the same effect as when people frequently use the word "irregardless".)

I only mention this because precise communication is required to get a team to manufacture a precise product.

I like the fact, that they are also the ones designing their own 3D metal printers, and staffing it in way that make me believe they are taking it seriously. No one is an expert at everything. Recognizing that, and getting the proper people to fill those holes, is most of the battle.

All drawing board stuff, manual machining or literal cams(ie screw machines), fundamentals of geometry pushed to the limits to get holes on strange angles to make the part work to how the mathematics wants it, real cutting edge stuff. Then obviously the miniaturisation of things like the tomahawk cruise missile being made possible by things like multi-axis machining(A quote I've heard is 6000 parts to 600). This is just an evolution of humans crazy quest to push the limits of turning rocks into shiny objects.

I'm having another case of 'hindsight is 20/20'.

3D printing had all sorts of problems at first with material strength and everything else... because it was so fundamentally different than what came before. For some reason, it never hit me that the response to that should be to embrace that, and re-engineer everything that goes into it. Not just the design, but the design *process*, not just the form of the metal (powder, wire, droplet), but the composition of the alloys you're using. To me this is one of those things that's just... so obvious in hindsight. Like, 'of course, that kind of work is going to produce results', but I never would have thought of it. That is some solid innovation/invention going on right there.

Heck, you've even got parallels to old stuff. Waaay back with blacksmithing, forging metal by beating on it was done for manufacturing reasons, not for the effect on the final structure. But the good designs accounted for that and used how it messed with the metal's properties to make better products.

3D printers are the technology I feel will change our lives in ways akin to the automobile, or the internet. Imagine being able to 3D print cheaper housing on a large scale in the matter of hours, out of recycled materials. We are still in the early stages of the technology, but the promise looks incredible.

This looks quite intriguing.  I would like to have seen a bit more about the process they have gone through to ensure that the tanks will hold pressure.  When the entire tank is made up of millions of welds, only one bad weld and your tank does not hold pressure and explodes on the launch pad.  I am sure that they have identified this challenge and addressed it but it would be nice to see what they did to address this challenge.  Rocketry at this scale is much harder than the rockets made for hobbyists in their backyards and the stakes/costs are much higher.  I will be convinced after a successful launch. So what I don't see happening is part inspection.  3D printing and machining (CNC) processes need a part inspection phase.   I assume we just didn't see that.  There must be something reading back the actual produced shape of the "as built" object. What about searching for air gaps in the weld, or contamination, or metallurgical flaws? Aluminum 3D printed parts must probably be analyzed via a variety of sensors/cameras.   There are ways to build large quantities with traditional aerospace CNC, once the designs are optimized.    CNC didn't get enough discussion here.  Why aren't they using a hybrid of "N different printing plus CNC" approach?   Machine Shop people wanna know.  CNC is the oldest form of 3D printing and still has a lot of application in aerospace engineering.  It's not "by hand with a hammer and a pair of metal sheers versus 3d printing with wire",  there are non-wire-based and non-powder-based non-by-hand ways of making things.

He says their 3D printed parts are stronger than traditional.....but he isn't comparing apples to apples. He said they develop and use specific alloys which means they're made of different materials. Plus they print in strengthening structures that traditionally built ones might not need.

If you do make the exact same design using the exact same materials both ways, I'd bet that traditionally parts would be stronger.

I'm not crapping on 3D printing in any way. It can make things that traditional methods just can't, but it's not a perfect replacement yet.

3D printing metal creates tiny imperfections . They account for these in their design but ideally printing becomes so good that the microscopic structure of the material becomes identical or even superior to casting or other methods. Hell, it could eventually print perfect atom by atom bonds that exceed anything possible by any method today. I expect a lot of 3D printing's weaknesses to be ironed out in the coming decades. I'm not sure if all of them can be and traditional manufacturing will likely still be better for some things, but I'd love to be wrong.

Is no one else seeing the fact that this is a RIDICULOUS waste of energy compared to normal building? Yeah the first example is also ridiculous, but not energy use wise...and now would be much faster and more efficient. You had big energy into making the wire, then HUGE energy to a continuous weld 24/7 plus all lasers, robots, etc on energy use. Bending a large piece of sheet metal then welding it together is magnitudes less energy demanding than a constant weld building it a drop at a time.

If the only option on say the moon in a completely unmanned process then having the technology is great, but doing it just because is using way more energy, plus eliminating how many jobs?? Doing complex parts is great, but for the tanks just seems wasteful and lazy. It may be "cheaper" for the company, but that's greed talking not having to pay workers to do the labor; but it's far more expensive for the environment. No one will live on Mars. Sorry to have to say this. :(

In exactly the same way no one lives in Antarctica. The only way to get there is to go and work there, and when your contract/season is over, you go home. You can't stay there. And you can't take a ship full of stuff, take it to Antarctica, unload it all, and then live there. Or even visit there, without permission.

Humans might be allowed to do two tours of Mars if the radiation shielding on the ships and on Mars itself can be made sufficiently effective. But I doubt it. One tour of Mars is all you'll get. And you'll be damned glad of it. Because going to Mars will suck most severely. You will most likely die if you're on the first few dozen trips.

The transit time can't be longer than 3 months, unless you tie two ships together, with 2km-long cables, and spin them up to 1G. Otherwise, humans arriving at Mars will be in terrible shape, just when they need to be in their very best condition. Zero G is no joke - and wrecks humans quite quickly.

Conditions on Mars will be disgustingly vile. Inhumane, in fact. You won't be allowed outside for a walk just because you feel like getting some vacuum/surface time. There will be no showers. You won't be able to surf the web in your time off - of which there will be practically none.

You better hope you stay healthy, too, and just as importantly, that your doctors and surgeons are in tip-top shape throughout the mission, and that they have an extensive medical suite at their disposal.


The good news is that it is possible humanity WILL establish research bases on Mars, and employ some very "lucky" people, to go on 2+ year missions.

The bad news is that a lot of them will get sick. Some of them will die - and in some not very pleasant ways - but exposure to vacuum leaves you conscious for about 10-12 seconds only, so you won't suffer long in that scenario. And no, there is no such thing as explosive decompression when going from 1-bar to 0-bar. :P

The cool thing is that we will get to see some crazy people do Mars, and it will stream back to earth 24/7.

As someone who's just finished a Material engineering degree and has done work on Additive Manufacturing (AM) I have several questions about this:

1 - Are there concerns about the mechanical properties of the material? AM parts have higher directionality of the properties in the build direction and so how would this effect the design
2 - If the rockets are to be reusable, what's the fatigue life like? And subsequently, what's the porosity like on the parts
3 - What's the cost of manufacture compared to normal manufacture and fuelling. If refuelling costs significantly more over time, is this method as advantageous at cost saving?
4 - The 5-10% mass extra due to roughness seems quite a lot when talking about rockets. And subsequently, if this design were to be make using a different method, how would the masses compare?
I'm sure there's a few more but i can't think of them right now.

As much as I'm a fan of 3D printing and AM and want to see it used more, using it to fully make rockets seems less advantageous then would be hoped - at least in my opinion. It seems more useful for single use/disposable rockets and highly complex parts though again, that's my own opinion.

this is different from regular hobby 3d printing for the reason that this is literally melting the layers together so the bond strength is equal to the metal strength. whereas in plastic printing the layers solidify as soon as they are laid down and the heat source moves away..so the layer adhesion strength is a fraction of the material's actual strength. a tube 3d printed in this orientation would be pretty weak and will fail cleanly along the layer lines...

For those not sheep and able to pay attention to the UFO situation, UFOs are consistently described as monolithic in construction, what we today would call 3D printing, and not just structural, but perfect atomic placement including electrical and other functionality in the same monolithic construction. Aluminium 3D printed rocket is probably not reusable, because of lesser melting points than steel. What we are looking at is dead end, the real holy grail is to print the rocket from steel. But 3D printing has own drowbacks, if we compare Space X Starship, they use precise rolled stainless steel sheet, it is also hardened by rolling and other operations, that mean, that the wall of your tank should be thinner and lighter. On the other hand, 3D print is not creating precise flat sheet, it does oposite, surface of printed sheet is not perfectly flat, it has many hilly places, thicness variess a lot and also it must be thicker, because there are no processes like rolling of steel to provide more strenght and desirable grain structure. 3D print must do further steps, to be competetive in rocket industry. Yes, you can skip lot of parts, but weight matters more, if we talk about rockets. If we make same rocket for same task, I think that 3D printed rocket would be 20-40% heavier, than rocklet made from rolled steel. Because 3D print does not provide perfect flat surface. In comparison, 3 mm of rolled stainless steel will be still strongre than 3 mm of 3D printed steel. Because of different production precess.

I can definitely see the advantage of 3d printing tech like rockets and reducing parts, but at the same time can see problems with that as well:

1) 3d printed parts because they are in essence "jointed" components (which previously were separate and could be taken appart) cannot be fixed because they cannot be taken apart so as to replace smaller broken components. The broken units have to be replaced with another fully 3D printed unit. If you will go to Mars, unless you have a fully functional 3d printer waiting for you on Mars, it will be impossible to fix equipment created via 3D printing.

2) the whole idea of updating your equipment via iteritive process (like patches to video games) might be great in many instances, but not when human lives are involved. Creating a less then perfect tube full of frozen explosive gasses, sticking well trained people on top of it and launching it with the attitudes of "pfft, we will make a version 3.2.5 if it blows up" could end up being careless...especially since astronauts cannot be 3d printed if they are blown up to piece.

Of course now I am wondering if the races in StarCraft use 3D printing. Zerg: obviously not. Protoss: It is meticulous but inefficient with a focus on quality over quantity, but it is impossible to know exactly since everything is built off site and warped (teleported) to the battlefield. Terrans (aka humans): StarCraft 2 was announced with a video showing the assembly process for power armor. It is clearly inspired by the robots at a car factory, but with each robot arm executing many different steps, one unit at a time. It's not really mass manufacturing, but allows you to fit the process into a single room. Ironically their software is advanced enough to adjust the the soldier moving around, but not enough to handle more than five orders at a time. Actually they only show the final assembly, and the Terran art style seems to always involve thousands of moving parts, so I still have to wonder how they make all of the tiny moving parts...maybe it is 3D printing!

(I am no expert and I have little knowledge about this subject because I don't actively look into it) I still think the moon is a better place to set up base first then aim for mars from the moon. It's closer (so if shiz hits the fan they are easier to rescue (I think it was only a few weeks to the moon, can't remember) compared to a few months journey and like a 2 year wait (if they are really unlucky) to be able to send people to mars to help (so basically if you screw up on mars your basically completely dead where as with the moon you have a larger chance of survival) , it's metal rich (from what I remember, so we can build the parts there if we want once we get the whole mining process working (the moon also has water (ice) on it so we can get oxygen and hydrogen (so we basically have the necessary supply (though limited) of oxygen, hydrogen and water to help kick things off)), it has low gravity (lower gravity means less fuel needed for take off meaning we can go further if we use the same rockets on the moon than on earth. lower gravity also means we can move the parts easier meaning we don't really need to use heavy duty machinery, we just need to secure it properly and ensure we can stop without the part dragging the machinery), the communication time would be shorter and with the moon being the testing grounds for space tech (I.e habitation, mining, food production, waste disposal, etc) it could shorten the time needed to research/create methods to increase the chances of surviving mars without it blowing up in our faces a few months after landing. Induction heating coils can be used for melting the metals and the heat generated from the metal production plants can be piped (using a liquid to circulate it) to the colony, improving energy efficiency because less energy would be needed for heating (one big plant wouldn't do it if we were providing some heat to a large colony, the pipes heat would lessen over the distance so we would probably need one big plant for main production and a few smaller plants connected to the pipe system along the way (the liquid would also need to be pumped fast so I wont reach it's boiling point (have no clue if this would work in practice). if your asking where we are going to get the energy from I'd say solar at the start then move to fusion, nuclear or thorium over time as the need for power increases (plus a few gigantic energy storage's for emergency power). I say solar because 1 day on the moon is I think 24~25 days, so 12 days of sun, and depending on how solar panels improve they may prove useful as a backup when they need to do maintenance or repair a reactor. The only other major problem/hurdle I see other than the vacuum of space is the moon dust.

This is all I can think of at this point in time without going in depth (to lazy to flesh stuff out or add more, got a ton but don't feel like writing a ton), may come back and edit it at some point. This probably has a ton of holes in it and I'm sure it does (oh and hope you enjoyed the wall of text instead of paragraphs or bullet points, was to lazy).

1) That texture IS going to affect the aerodynamics. It will transition to turbulent flow much quicker.
2) An EBM or SLS part is NOT stronger than a forged one because not all of the grains will evenly melt/get distributed so it is not isotropic, whereas a forged one get have the grains compressed and shaped into the direction of force you desire. It's close with EBM (Like 97%) but not stronger.

I have not heard any good reason to spend earth's resources to colonize Mars right now other than to mitigate risk by becoming multiplanetary. But frankly, I don't think that is good enough, there are no immediate threats that require urgent action. For safety and reasons of equality, I believe humanity needs to progress a great deal, both socially and politically, before we should be considering colonizing Mars just for the sake of becoming multiplanetary. On the other hand, if we were to identify some other more compelling benefit to society in which it would make sense to colonize, then by all means do it, but I just have not heard any evidence of that.  Micro-gravity environments of orbital stations may offer some interesting production opportunities however, and I agree that may be viable right now; just not Mars, yet.

The roughness not being an issue aerodynamically is an interesting point.   I suspect there are some caveats to that statement.  the physics of the boundary layer can maybe explain some of the idea that it doesn't matter, but what about the falling to earth part?  I suppose there is no re-entry aspect to this, in which case the boundary layer dynamics would be quite different.  Also, the straightness to within a human hair is a little hard to believe, though if real, is amazing of course.   The roughness is already well beyond say even a hundred human hairs....so straightness would have to be quite a lot of measurements with significant statistical manipulations to actually determine how straight it was, and even then you are looking at a cloud of data.

I'm an aerospace engineer so thought I'd add my 2 cents:  Most AM engineers hate when Additive Manufacturing is referred to as 3D printing.  With powder bed fusion, there is a significant risk of internal voids which spells huge problems for service life (durability and damage tolerance, not an issue for space).  It's rather unfair to say that AM is stronger, but it does allow significant material flexibility because you're essentially creating the material and part simultaneously in the fusion process.

Electric cars don't have significantly fewer parts. You replace the engine and gearbox with an electric transaxle which removes lots of parts. However, you still need all the other car components: Power steering, air conditioning, brakes, 12V circuits, lights, stereo etc. Now you add all the high voltage components like the charger, motor controller, and step down converter. Most of all, the battery which has hundreds or thousands of cells. I would say that electric cars have the same or more parts than a similar combustion car, just fewer moving parts.

Back in High School, I took the first year welding course. The optional and most difficult assignment for the first year students was filling in the hole. There was the arc-welding filling in the hole assignment and the acetylene torch welding filling in the hole assignment. This was tricky because you need to melt to melt the metal you have deposited to get it to stick to the new metal but if you keep it melted for too long (or heat it up too much), it will either sag down or drip away, re-forming the hole. 17 years later, and it just occurs to me that I was manually performing 3D printing with metals.

Been seeing a lot of comments here suggesting this thing can't fly on its face because the tank is about 10% heavier than it would be if it were constructed with normal methods.

That's 10% of the tank. Not the entire rocket; most of a rocket's weight is its fuel, not its inert mass. Take the Solid State Booster, those thin boosters on the side of the external tank that the Space Shuttle rode on. Those, fully loaded, are about 590 metric tons, or 1.3 million pounds each. Its inert weight - just the empty rocket itself without fuel or payload? Just over 87 metric tons, or approximately 190,000 pounds.

Now, assuming that the ratio will be about the same for the Terran rockets, as a ballpark estimate, we can divide the inert mass by the total payload. which comes out to be a little below .15. In other words, the inert mass of the rocket is 15% of the total weight of said rocket ready to launch. 10% of 15? 1.5%. They're literally dealing with a 1.5% increase in overall mass just from this ballpark estimate, which is nowhere near as critical as 10% of the total weight - that'd be 2/3rds of an entirely new rocket!

A few years ago I was telling some people in a bar that additive manufacturing would allow industry, and them, to print objects on demand. It sounded fantastical to them and I was laughed at, but made a few bets. I should've made bigger bets. Now to win a few more over whether or not traditional manufacturing techniques such as milling are now obsolete. My bet is no, because milling and additive manufacturing have a mirrored fiduciary profile, so even though additive manufacturing is going to displace a lot of milling, there's still going to be a need for traditional milling techniques in industry for many years, and decades to come.
Now if some enterprising software engineer will figure out how to code a conversion table for additive to milling, and milling to additive, as well as for casting, etc, then we'll all have much more powerful, flexible tools to determine the most effective way to make the things that we want. just remember folks, when you're talking about speed and waste and everything... the material waste factor is something like 75-90%+ with subtractive manufacturing. meaning that's how much goes back to be recycled without ever being used. machined away as chips
The space shuttle main engine injector plates had 250 some-odd holes. each at a specific place, and a specific angle. to make it took weeks because each hole had to be lined up by hand, so that's probably 3 hours of setup, drill the hole, ream the hole, an hour of breakdown, then repeat...
today we have CNC milling machines, so instead of weeks, that will take days to machine out of a single billet of material, and it'll have to be repositioned multiple times, and might even need multiple different types of CNC machines with different capabilities. and just imagine a tool breaking in the last process. the whole part is now scrapped.

3D printing rocket engines is a great idea, which is why everyone already moved to that before Relativity Space was founded.  3D printing cylindrical tanks on the other hand is a terrible idea.  Not quite as bad as machining orthogrids and then bump forming them into cylinders, but SpaceX' technique of welding flat metal sheets together and then welding on stringers is much cheaper and faster while giving a stronger and lighter weight end result.  Which is also a type of additive manufacturing, but with enormously less time, energy, and equipment needed.  If SpaceX was resting on its laurels then the Terran R might have a chance of beating out the Neutron or New Glen for the second provider slot, but with the speed Starship is coming along it will likely be obsolete before it ever launches.

A much better and sustainable goal should be the expansion of our resources and energy production. This has always been the catalyst for a massive increase in production and ultimately living standards. Start mining asteroids, placing solar collectors, building habitats and other means of reaching orbit like skyhooks, mass drivers, orbital rings etc. These purposes will need lots of rockets to get building materials and even robots in to orbit and will further expand the capabilities of humanity as a whole. Mars doen't do this, its just a cute little settlement on a useless planet. Our goal should be to improve our current situation on earth as much as possible with what space has to offer in abundance. From there you can build more and do more in space and then consider colonizing other planets.

CO2 emissions from rocket launches are estimated to be about 62.5 metric tonnes per person. The average American consumes goods which release about 7.5 tonnes of CO2 per year. That is 8.33 years of emissions in a single day.

The CO2 is released at varying altitudes, but much of it is used to achieve the speeds necessary to orbit the planet, meaning it is released high in the atmosphere, meaning its impact is higher than ground based emissions.

Lets be extremely generous and say that through incredible effort companies like this manage to lift people and all the supplies they need to orbit for an unimaginably efficient 50 tonnes per person. Moving 1000 people to orbit would lead to the release of 50 kilotonnes of CO2 (Realistically life support equipment to get a person to Mars, set up for a lifetime of incredibly demanding work, would be at least on order of magnitude more massive than their own body)

This at a time when world wide emissions need to drop to zero in order to avoid death on a scale greater than any war in history has caused.

While I see plenty of ways this technology could be very beneficial for the planet we live on, it is frankly frightening to see someone who should be fully aware of this reality espousing a plan that will doom us to having to terraform Earth at the same time as Mars. @veritasium too, you have to do better than this.

issues I've known: (1) welding/printing material is often more expensive than just buying the fabricated materials (buying a 5 ton pipe for a simple section of the product vs printing all that wire anyway). (2) consistancy of robotic welds can still be pretty lacking, as molten metal often doesn't behave consistently, and programming the robot to adapt is difficult. (easier for thicker metals though but rockets are typically thin) (3) thin metals are even harder to print, so the overall design would need to be heavier, which is a huge issue for rockets (it looks like they are accepting the heavier weight), (4) high performance metal objects aren't great for welding all of it, like a need for forged or heat tempered molecular bonds within the metal. (so cool they've developed their own alloys!) (5) printing objects in high quantity often is way more expensive than having dedicated tooling to mass produce it (3d printing takes a long time)
Automation is really making things bigger and better and more accessible. I wanna fast forward to 2050.

This could be a huge assumption, but I think that anybody in the welding community that actually knows what's going on when they weld won't be surprised by anything in this video. Think about it. They basically took a really good welding process and attached it to a robotic arm with very fine-tuned control.

I showed this video to a very old friend of mine who was an amazing welder and he was surprised either. It's actually so obvious that I'm surprised Elon or somebody else wasn't already doing it. But that is sometimes how progress works, I guess.

I'm definitely not trying to play down what they are doing. It has to be very controlled and precise to work, but they are basically getting software to do with humans are struggling to do with a spool of wire (or rods) and high voltage in their hands. It's really good to see this kind of stuff happening

I feel like this stuff would be great for colony infrastructure: just ship or mine the metal and then assemble storage, tanks air tubes etc. whatever is needed for a space colony on site. It just seems like rockets need such good margins in terms of weight and aerodynamics that a quantity over quality approach doesn’t fit the problem. However is looks like it has great potential for rapid prototyping and research.

Because you are essentially welding the structure, you introduce heat affected zones into the metal, which can reduce the material's yield strength significantly. So, it is only 10% heavier, but you can only stress the material to around 70% of what you could hot-rolled or extruded material. Not to mention the significant friction due to the roughness of the printed surface. This may be insignificant compared to the amount of thrust produced from an aerodynamic standpoint, but high-pressure vessels WILL suffer due to the stress concentrations created.

The advantage of 3D Printers is that they can print any shape, so they aren't limited to printing rockets.

They could branch out to printing just about any kind of low volume metal structure that would take far longer to fabricate.

I also see a lot of promise in their tech for creating scientific experiments and instruments.

These are often very costly and often only serve a very limited purpose while having rather high complexity which causes design iteration to be a nightmare.

So being able to bring down the cost and iteration time down is a huge boon.

Glamourous vision, but somewhat far fetched. As SM said, if you're going to build a lot of rockets, this is not the way to go about it. Though as a way to get something working - eventually - for minimal infrastructure build, yeah why not? They'll discover that the launcher market is over-supplied, and it's hard to make money out of it.

Citing airliners as things that are big and slow to produce is misplaced; Airbus already can make 2 A32xxxx airliners a day, soon moving to 2.3 a day, plus a few other types too. They're seriously good at it, being past-masters at designing for manufacture. And whilst a car might be simpler than a rocket, the number of parts assembled per day in your average car factory is truly enormous.

"Conventional" manufacturing has no problems achieving rapid efficient build, if the market is there to warrant it. The reason why "old space" hasn't achieved high rate production is because there wasn't - and to a large extent still isn't - the market demand for it.

Using Titanium / aluminum to build the rocket engines is really the best way to use 3D printing.  For tanks, you need very UNIFORM flat metal, and you can't get that with 3D-printing. I don't see how it would makes sense to 3d print the tanks like that.  It might be a game changer for really intricate parts, sure, but a tank is a pretty simple structure.  Reducing its part count from ~50 (including braces, baffles, etc) to 1 surely doesn't make up for the time and energy costs of metal 3d printing, not to mention the weight hit.  He said it 'only' adds 5-10% to the weight, but on a rocket that is an enormous deal.  If you increased the dry mass of the space shuttle by 5% you cut its payload to the ISS in half.  10% means it can't make it at all.
5-10% waste weight is tremendous for a rocket...
It makes sense, in that 3D printing is best for making complicated products in relatively low volume. A space rocket is a pretty good example of this sort of thing.

"The only acceptable reason to use seperate parts is planned maintenance" - My university construction professor

If you fly something once, using bolts to hold parts together is simply bad practise. If you don't plan on disassembling something later down the line, making it a single piece is not only the sensible option, it's the only viable strategy to stay competitive in the future. We've allready seen it with smartphones. They have no planned maintenance cycle, and nowadays, they don't offer any option to change a screen or a battery yourself. We won't even talk about the electronics, those are allready complete single units. Reducing partcount is going to be the future for all production industries.

Weirdly enough, having a faster prototype production rate doesn't speed up research and development as much as I would have originally thought. What it does do, though, is change the workflow. We were already modeling everything before, but we were spending a lot of time iteratively improving our application specific models so our prototypes were more accurately represented. Now, instead of spending extra time improving our application specific models, were are spending time iteratively improving our physical prototypes. Perhaps if any time is left, correcting the models, but that isn't the priority anymore. With such a fast turnover rate of physical prototypes, high accuracy models aren't as necessary and we don't have the extra time to dedicate to it, with prototypes churning out so fast.

At the end of the day, the time periods are not too dissimilar, except perhaps that now we have fewer unforeseen flaws in final production due to the use of real physical models in the development stage. Basically, we can risk prototypes being potentially flawed now. By the time we have a prototype as developed as our first prototype would have been, about the same amount of time has passed. Project managers are getting spoiled by having a new model in their hands every month to check off a checklist, it FEELS like progress is being made faster, but it really isn't. Just less code, more cad.

The "advancing metal 3D printed manufacturing" part of Relativity: Awesome.

The "rocket" part? Not so much. When he talks about the added mass of 3D printing, he casually mentions 10% like it's no big deal. Most rockets have payload fractions less than 5%, 10% extra mass on the rocket is HUGE.

Also, the structure of the rocket isn't really the most time demanding part. Turning a tank into a rocket is. Thousands of meters of wiring, sensors, plumbing, that's where it's at. And that part will be as slow with 3D printing as without.

Reusability is much more revolutionary for Rockets than 3D printing tanks.

Rocket Lab has been 3D printing their engines for a while, and baking their tanks out of carbon fiber, so 3D printing engines is already well proven to be a viable move. The rest, maybe not so much. Specially using what's essentially a MIG welder, since the end result isn't really mass-optimized.

I do not believe what he says about the roughness not adding any aerodynamic drag.

What we're looking at is a giant scaled up version of engine exhaust/intake headers. The original cast headers in your car are just that... they're cast. Where the air flows is rough to the touch. When you want to improve horsepower, you purchase performance headers where the inside of that airflow passage is ground down and smooth-bored. Because it creates less drag.

I 100% do not believe that statement. Now -- if he plans on just saying "screw it" and poppin' a fat engine on this bad boy to overcome the drag, that's a different story.

The real winning technology here is the ability to fabricate the engines in fewer parts with fewer machines. Traditional plumbing can get really complicated, so having it simply be a file is really great for simplicity. Now, Spacex is fabricating raptor engines every few days at this point, but they have a large, fully tooled factory with many machines to do so, but Relativity just needs a 3D printer and some (lots) of wire.

Building a rocket factory on Mars similar to what they have here is a great move. Because most of what they need is printers and wire feedstock, the supply chain and factory can be set up much more quickly with much less equipment shipped over, which reduces costs significantly. It'll be exiting to see their rockets fly.

However, I am concerned about the mass gain on the main rocket body, though. He quoted 5-10%, which does not sound like much, but in aerospace terms, that's a large reduction in payload. You could make an argument that the cost reduction and speed gain allows more rockets to fly, thus getting more payload to orbit, but another solution to this would just to weld large plates together for the sides of the tanks, which I believe is the traditional way of doing it. Of course, the tradeoff for that method (and thus the performance gain) is the larger amount of ground infrastructure needed to do those welds. If you're targeting volume production, that's the way to go, not 3D printing, if just because of the massive reduction in the welds you need to do. 3D printing can only get so fast, and welding plates together is essentially the same as a massive reduction in the tool path length of a 3D print. That's how SpaceX stacks starships in days/weeks rather than months. You just need the infrastructure available, which can't be said for Mars, and has a large up-front cost, both in money and materials (not to mention energy).

I like how these guys are always touting "Yeah, we can make space affordable for the average Joe!"... if you do the math, it's simply physically impossible to make space travel actually affordable for the average person.

Orbital velocity: ~30km/s
Average person: ~80kg
Energy to put them in orbit: ~72,000 MJ
Energy density of Gasoline: ~35MJ/L (basically the cheapest source of energy available)
Price of Gasoline: ~$1/L
-> Cost to put a person's worth of mass up to orbital velocity: ~$2000

That's $2000... _absolute floor price_, assuming 100% efficiency and not even counting a share of the mass of the rocket they flew in, the partial distance to orbit part of the fuel had to be carried, the air and water to support that person, the mass of whatever gets them back to earth, etc etc.

Great idea to reduce tooling cost. I have a critique/suggestion though about the fuselages.
Fuselages of course have to be very light and strong, especially for small vehicles, to get good delta v. You have the tools available to 3D print internal fuselage grids, but don't use them by printing vertically. I know this goes somewhat against the no tooling idea, but it would be so much more efficient to print a grid on aluminum plates, roll them, and friction stir weld them together. It wouldn't require that much extra tooling; most companies machine the gridding which is way more expensive and requires huge custom CNC machines. This will reduce the fuselage mass for 3 reasons.
1. Even skin thickness. Only minimum skin thickness matters so no wasted material that naturally results from welding in vertical layers like this.
2. You can actually do gridding now. By printing the fuselage vertically like this, you just can't print internal gridding because there's no support, which I'm sure is the only reason why you don't.
3. Proper aluminum alloy plates are way stronger than these welds, so skin thickness can further be reduced.
There are also other benefits like not wasting 90% of print time on the simplest part, which means these rockets can probably be made in a week rather than 60 days.
All-in-all you could probably halve the mass of the fuselage by printing on plates, rolling, and then friction stir welding the sections together, and almost doubling the vehicle's performance. Printing is great but yeah, don't go too far unless it makes sense, that's my 2 cents.

If we assume this rocket will be successful, the most amazing part of this project is not the scale of the printers, nor the "vision" of the start up CEO. 3D printing is great for certain things, however it is really not superior than traditional methods at building flat cylindrical large scale parts. In performance, he says 5-10% mass gain which is huge, and in tolerance and material properties. His comment that they can provide superior strength or stiffness properties with this method is simply not true, a welded 3D printed metal will always have residual thermal strain which will reduce is strength capability in comparison to a traditional tempering cycle applied to conventional alloys. 3D printing has huge scaling issues as well because it takes far too long to manufacture one part. While I think many new technologies here are interesting, they do not have great scalability.

ok this and the driverless car video seem at least under researched.  They both focus on a single company and fail to provide context about competitors in the industry.  For example the guy from relativity was basically boasting about being able to produce a engine in under a month which is very impressive compared to NASA but that is the thing compared to others in the commercial industry it seems very slow.  Rocket Lab prints their components for a engine in 24 hours and Spacex has been pumping out their new raptor engine every 48 hours.  While I agree that 3D printing is going to speed up all aspects of manufacturing it isn't the golden ticket that has allowed the acceleration in the space industry.  That would actually be the change in methodology or as Scott Manely put it the "silicon valley engineering" methodology.  The perfect example that proves that is Spacex and their starship program.  2 years ago they flew a very basic test article that was basically a glorified water tower and now they just stacked largest and most powerful rocket in the world that in a few months will hopefully fly and they didn't need to 3D print the entire thing to do it.

Ok, mixed reaction to this...
There are parts of this that I think are genius, and others that are diabolically stupid.
A 12" shifter is a versatile tool, it can screw up a great many tasks and perform a few quite well. It is versatile. 3d printing is like that. Using that exact 3d printing to make the combustion chambers and nozzles, I completely 100% agree with them ~ that's genius. Using it to make the whole body of the craft, I think that's a bit dumb. Might it work? Yes, it might, but it's not the quickest or simplest or cheapest or strongest or most proven or most logical. Good engineering - and this very emphatically does hold true in IT and computers and software - is to choose the design and the materials and the tools which are appropriate for the job at hand and use them properly and sensibly to do it. 3d printing the chambers & nozzles like that, I'm all in favour. Doing it with welding, for the whole craft, that's not smart or cheap or efficient or ... We have built aeroplanes out of aluminium for 80 years now, but we don't build them that way. Any questions about why not?
Q: What is the main body material is used for a Falcon 9?
A: Carbon fibre.
Q: What main body material is used on Starship? (Bigger, newer, heavier, reusable for years?)
A: Good old fashioned stainless steel.
Q: Is it 3d printed?
A: No. It's made by boilermakers like a water-tower.
Alright, that's not entirely true, they do have a turntable and a welding robot and many of the welds are computer controlled, not done by human hands any more, but they're welding sheets of stainless plate about 2m on a side together. I'm sorry, that isn't smart, that's really dumb. Doing it for the engines, I think that's a great idea, but doing the whole thing that way...

I'm genuinely excited by this. However, there are a lot of unanswered questions. For a start, 3D printing can produce something that is structurally optimal - complex internal structure which ends up looking like bone. This was hinted at in Relativity's promo video for Terran-R. But what you see here is very conventional flat geometry and simple stiffener rings. It begs the question of how Relativity is going to solve some of the inherent problems in their build-via-welding process. Easy with rotational symmetry. A lot harder if you want to create complex (and more mass efficient) structural geometries.

Also with regard to their promo video for Terran-R. The booster has fixed, stubby winglets. Why? Its using grid fins to provide braking. I'd also like to know more about their strategy for reuse. And on the upper stage as well. Does it tail land? How do they propose to solve the same problems SpaceX came up against with sloshing of propellants? How do they reduce the processing costs of refurbishment/reuse?

And.. lots more unanswered questions.. Please go back with a list! :)

I think the key thing they’ve got here is that ability to iterate so rapidly.
That could be a really exciting niche for them to fill - someone needs a better nozzle or a better tube or a better second stage, cryogenics, whatever - these guys get a contract to run through a whole bunch of algorithmically generated iterations on that item, then sell the designs to the larger companies so they can produce them at scale.
Like Scott said, in the long run it becomes cheaper when you standardize manufacturing, but in the short term, developing incrementally better pieces for other companies with standardized manufacturing could really speed up this kind of Space Race 2.0 we’ve got going on right now.
Super exciting stuff!

While once rocket production scales up, I doubt we'll be using fully 3d printed rockets... we will probably use many parts in rockets.
What I'm more interested in is if they have plans to try and set up a 3d printer in space for printing metal, and if they could get that to work. If you can ship up a few tons of metal as spools of wire, and and a 3d printer, then you could build a basic structure or even airtight walls and such for a space station for possibly very cheap, ignoring normal limits on sizes from rocket ferrings and stuff. Similarly for building bases and structures on other worlds, in space 3d printing. While we see plenty of demo videos with them printing with cement like materials from local soil, if we can 3d print from metal sent over in a vacuum or near to it, that has some clear advantages and uses. And while quite different from doing so in atmosphere like they are now, they are still doing a lot of good work solving issues with printing structures in metal as it is that will give them a head start to challenge those future problems in other environments.

I'm looking forward to seeing how the balance is struck in the future between this and conventional manufacturing methods.  I personally think that conventional sheet metal will still maintain a solid niche as it is so efficient, but part counts will definitely fall.  The lower bound on total part counts will probably be limited mostly by the need for different material properties on different parts and especially by the need for maintenance and repair.  The lower your parts count, the larger the chunk is you have to replace when something is wearing out on a reusable system.

I work with 3D printed Ti in a biotech setting, it's a different 3D printing method (powder bed) so I'm not sure if this would see some of the same issues. Namely, fatigue strength (sub yield point repeated loading) is often significantly worse for 3D parts because they have higher surface roughness, more inclusions, and voids from expanding gases during melting which all produce stress concentrations. These issues can be mitigated somewhat through hot isostatic pressing but it seems like this rocket would be too big for that. It also looks like this is being done in a relatively open environment, meaning it's got some particulate in the air which will increase the number of potential particles that get stuck in the melt pool. So is fatigue strength an issue for these rockets with this type of build? What testing has been done on that front with an eye towards the stated goal of reusability? Pretty neat idea, hope the nitty gritty details get worked out cause that'll be the key here!

One thing worth noting: Aluminum is an ideal material for 3D printing, because it recycles very efficiently. With paper and plastic, what you get out of recycling tends to be of lower quality, but with Aluminum you get a high quality product. This makes it ideal for fast-prototyping or machines that occasionally mess up a print.
